metadata.titleEn: Spatial-temporal continuous evapotranspiration product across China based on thermal infrared and microwave data (2001-2020)
metadata.description:
Evapotranspiration (ET) is a key parameter in the hydrologic cycle and energy cycle parameters. Over the years, thermal infrared-based models is the main methods for generating ET products. Although spatia-temporally continous land surface temperature (LST) products have been developed to drive the thermal infrared model, spatial gaps still occured when applying these model to large regions due to data missing and cloud cover. Therefore, in this study, we drived TSEB-SM model across China to estimate ET and developed a resonstruction strategy (DNN-ETo) to fill the spatial gaps. This reconstruction framework, combining the deep nerual network (DNN) and reference ET (ETo), is a two-step process for reconstructing ET. This ET product based on TSEB-SM and DNN-ETo method have achieved complete coverage across China. Besides, the accuracy of this ET product had been validated at 20 EC sites which including various landcover types, and indicated a good performances with a average bias of -0.17 mm day-1 and average RMSE of 1.02 mm day-1. Otherwise, the results of evaluation also suggested that this ET product was able to accurately respond to changes in vegetation transpiration and soil evaporation caused by soil moisture stress in arid and semi-arid regions of China.
The dataset (spatial-temporal continuous evapotranspiration product across China from 2001 to 2020) include evapotranspiration (ET), Transpiration (T) and Evaporation (E). This dataset was stored by a Network Common Data Form (NetCDF), with a temporal and spatial resolution of daily and 0.01°, covering the entire China region and spanning the period 2001.01.01-2020.12.31. For the convenience of the researchers, this study provides data not only at the daily scale, but also at the monthly and annual scales.
metadata.instructions: File name: the surface evaporation data stored in NetCDF format, the name of the file as "VV_Daily_YYYYDDD. Nc", including YYYY representative years, DDD on behalf of the Julian date.Data acquisition methods: the data can be directly by ArcGIS software to open.It is recommended to use Python environment GDAL and NetCDF4 module for processing, a simple processing code has been uploaded to the attachment.

background: The two-source energy balance (TSEB) model using the land surface temperature (LST) as a key boundary has been used to estimate land surface evapotranspiration (ET) over various landcovers and environmental conditions. Energy balance models using the land surface temperature (LST) as a key boundary condition have been applied to estimate convective and radiative exchange across the land-atmosphere interface. The two-source energy balance (TSEB) model proposed by Norman et al. (1995) has been shown to address key convective and radiative exchange processes for many complex canopies, additionally partitioning the ET into E and T. In the original TSEB model, the value of Priestley-Taylor coefficient αPT is initially assumed to equal its classic value of 1.26, and the value would decline as the canopy became water stressed which would be indicated by a modeled derived elevated soil temperature resulting in a negative daytime soil latent heat flux or condensation due to soil sensible heat flux exceeding the soil surface available energy, which is a non-physical solution during daytime convective conditions. The soil and canopy water use not only affects their kinetic temperatures which are estimated via the radiometric temperature observation, the key boundary of the TSEB model, and both temperatures are correlated to atmospheric demand and the soil moisture content affecting the evaporation from the soil surface and transpiration from plant stomata.
research objective: In this study, the objective is (i) to define stress indices for constraining evaporation from soil surface and transpiration from the canopy, (ii) revise the TSEB model by introducing the surface soil moisture stress indices (TSEB-SM) coupled to the evaporation and transpiration algorithm to estimate more accurately the soil evaporation and plant transpiration over study areas spanning well-watered to extremely dry soil moisture conditions.
challenges: The ET and E and T partitioning can be measured at canopy and patch scale representative areas, but it is very difficult to extrapolate these measurements to field, landscape and regional scales. However, under advective conditions where energy is being added beyond the available energy (net radiation less soil heat flux) the TSEB model is unable to account through any iterative solution for this additional evaporative demand but is shown to be related to the vapor pressure deficit (Agam et al., 2012). This can result in an underestimation of T and ET being underestimated under such advective conditions (Song et al., 2016).
methods: Four in situ/tower-based micrometeorological and remote sensing observations were selected to evaluate both the TSEB-SM and original TSEB model. The sensible (H) and latent (LE) heat fluxes were measured by eddy covariance (EC) systems with a sampling frequency of 10 Hz and a description of the data post-processing can be found in Liu et al. (2018). The soil moisture and temperature were measured at various depths (2, 4, 10, 20, 40, 80, 120, 160 cm) under the ground; here, the soil moisture measurement at 4 cm depth was used to calculate the soil stress factor for soil evaporation. Three heat transfer plates were buried at 6 cm with soil thermocouples above the plate for computing the heat storage term at each site for estimating the soil heat flux.
dataset: The meteorological and surface heat fluxes measurements were obtained from four flux towers which were deployed over grassland (2013 – 2017), irrigated cropland (2013 – 2017), sparse shrub-forest (2014 – 2017) and desert steppe (2014 – 2016) in the Heihe river basin (Fig. 1).
findings: While the results showed that the TSEB-SM model produced similar agreement in the fluxes and ET as the original TSEB for the cropland and grassland sites, TSEB-SM model performance was notably improved at the shrub-forest and desert steppe sites with a significant reduction in mean absolute percent difference in daily ET from nearly 65% to 25% and from approximately 50% to 40%, respectively.

background: Satellite retrievals of thermal infrared data from the Earth's surface when combined with the surface energy balance equation are widely used to monitor land surface evapotranspiration (ET). The Two-source Energy Balance model using information on Soil Moisture as another key constraint (TSEB-SM) improves model performance and utility. Satellite based thermal infrared data provides an advance for estimating ET, E and T using energy balance models with global coverage and daily temporal coverage.
research objective: Here, high resolution satellite soil moisture data from SMAP (Soil Moisture Active Passive) were used to provide soil water boundary conditions for the TSEB-SM model.
challenges: Unfortunately thermal infrared based models using this approach have a systematic positive bias with ET during soil water stress conditions.
methods: This SMAP driven TSEB-SM approach was applied in the Heihe river basin in China across a wide range of soil moisture conditions using MODIS thermal infrared land surface temperature (LST) data. The ET estimates from TSEB-SM were validated using flux tower measurements over the main land cover types in the study area and compared with the results from the original TSEB model.
dataset: The study area encompassed all catchments associated with the Heihe river basin, about 143 × 10^3 km^2, which is located at the arid region of northwestern China. The meteorological and fluxes were collected from four flux towers which are located at relatively homogenous surfaces and named A’rou (grassland) in an upstream catchment, Daman (cropland) and Huazhaizi (steppe) in midstream, Sidaoqiao (riparian forest) in a downstream location in the Heihe river basin. The soil moisture data supplied by the NASA SMAP satellite mission was downscaled from 9 km to 1 km to ensure the spatial resolution was consistent between the soil moisture and land surface temperature used in the model (Reichle et al., 2018).
findings: The comparison showed that the TSEB-SM approach reduced the RMSE error in latent heat flux estimates by 5 % to 20 % at satellite overpass time, and TSEB-SM outperformed the original TSEB model in daily ET estimates (RMSE values of 1.0 mm/d versus 1.5 mm/d, respectively) across all validation sites. The magnitude of the TSEB-SM improvements were larger early and late in the growing season and in arid areas, consistent with soil moisture improving estimates of ET particularly under times of higher water stress. The use of SMAP satellite soil moisture data with the TSEB-SM model increased the reliability of ET estimation and provides an improved capacity for continuous monitoring of drought effects on the global water cycle.

Verification.Question: Does the Two-source Energy Balance model using the land surface temperature (LST) as a key boundary condition provide accurate estimates of evapotranspiration across various land covers and environmental conditions?
Can the TSEB-SM model outperform the original TSEB model in estimating daily evapotranspiration, particularly in arid areas or under conditions of higher water stress?

Disjunctive.Question: Which data collection method is more effective for measuring surface heat fluxes: eddy covariance systems, satellite thermal infrared data, or in situ soil moisture sensors?
When dealing with cloud cover and data gaps, is it preferable to rely on thermal infrared models, microwave remote sensing, or a model reconstruction framework?

Concept Completion.Question: Where are the flux towers located that provide meteorological and flux data for evaluating remote sensing models in the field of evapotranspiration?
What challenges are faced in extrapolating evapotranspiration measurements from small scales to larger scales in remote sensing studies?

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge encountered during the extrapolation of ET partitioning measurements from a small scale to a regional scale?
Example.Answer: A challenge is the difficulty in extrapolating ET and its components' measurements from a canopy or patch scale to field, landscape, and regional scales, particularly under advective conditions where additional energy complicates accurate estimation.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a dataset that integrates soil moisture data from satellite observations to improve ET estimation models?
Example.Answer: An example of such a dataset includes the use of high-resolution soil moisture data from the SMAP satellite, which was downscaled and used to provide soil water boundary conditions for the TSEB-SM model, improving ET estimation in the Heihe river basin.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the main challenges in collecting accurate land surface temperature data for use in evapotranspiration models over large areas?
Feature Specification.Answer: cloud cover, data gaps, spatial and temporal discontinuities, accuracy under different atmospheric conditions, land cover types

Quantification.Question: What is the temporal resolution of a dataset that provides evapotranspiration data across China?
How many flux towers were used to collect meteorological and surface heat fluxes measurements in a specific research approach in the Heihe river basin?
What is the spatial resolution of a dataset developed for surface evapotranspiration estimation in China?

Definition.Question: What is the TSEB-SM model in the context of evapotranspiration estimation?
Definition.Answer: The TSEB-SM model is a revised version of the two-source energy balance model that incorporates surface soil moisture stress indices to more accurately estimate soil evaporation and plant transpiration over various soil moisture conditions, from well-watered to extremely dry.

Definition.Question: What does 'eddy covariance (EC) systems' mean in the context of measuring sensible and latent heat fluxes?
Definition.Answer: Eddy covariance (EC) systems are micrometeorological instruments used to measure the sensible and latent heat fluxes by capturing data at a high sampling frequency (e.g., 10 Hz), which is then processed to evaluate energy exchange processes between the land surface and the atmosphere.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the data collection challenges faced by thermal infrared-based models differ from those encountered when using soil moisture data from satellite sources in the context of evapotranspiration estimation?
Comparison.Answer: Thermal infrared-based models often encounter challenges due to cloud cover, which can obstruct satellite observations, leading to data gaps. Additionally, they tend to have a positive bias in estimating evapotranspiration under soil water stress conditions. On the other hand, using soil moisture data from satellites like SMAP can improve the model's performance during periods of high water stress by providing more accurate boundary conditions for soil moisture. However, satellite soil moisture data may require downscaling to match the spatial resolution of thermal infrared data, which can introduce its own set of challenges.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes inaccuracies or spatial gaps when estimating evapotranspiration using thermal infrared models over large regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Inaccuracies or spatial gaps in estimating evapotranspiration using thermal infrared models over large regions are mainly caused by cloud interference and data loss. These factors can lead to missing spatial information when the model is applied across extensive areas.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why might thermal infrared-based models have a systematic positive bias in ET estimates during soil water stress conditions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Thermal infrared-based models might have a systematic positive bias in ET estimates during soil water stress conditions due to the inability of these models to accurately account for soil moisture stress. This can result in an overstated estimation of evapotranspiration under such conditions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenge of scaling ET and its components from canopy and patch scales to field and regional scales?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Scaling ET and its components from canopy and patch scales to field and regional scales is challenging due to the complexity of advective conditions where additional energy is introduced beyond the available energy. This energy cannot be accounted for through iterative solutions in models, leading to underestimation errors.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of using thermal infrared and microwave remote sensing data collaboratively in evapotranspiration datasets for large-scale regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using thermal infrared and microwave remote sensing collaboratively can lead to the development of spatially and temporally continuous evapotranspiration datasets that cover large-scale regions like China. This approach helps to overcome spatial gaps caused by cloud cover and data loss, ensuring reliable performance under various weather conditions and accurately reflecting soil moisture stress effects on vegetation transpiration and soil evaporation.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the introduction of surface soil moisture stress indices in the TSEB-SM model impact the estimation of soil evaporation and plant transpiration?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The introduction of surface soil moisture stress indices in the TSEB-SM model improves the accuracy of estimating soil evaporation and plant transpiration, especially across a range of soil moisture conditions from well-watered to extremely dry. This enhancement leads to more precise partitioning of evapotranspiration components, as indicated by improved model performance in diverse environments, such as shrub-forest and desert steppe areas.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the goal of using high-resolution satellite soil moisture data from missions like SMAP in conjunction with energy balance models for monitoring evapotranspiration?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to improve the reliability and accuracy of evapotranspiration estimates by using high-resolution satellite soil moisture data to provide critical boundary conditions, particularly enhancing model performance during periods of soil water stress and enabling continuous monitoring of drought effects on global water cycles.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are stress indices defined and used in the TSEB-SM model to improve the accuracy of soil evaporation and plant transpiration estimates?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Stress indices are defined to constrain evaporation from the soil surface and transpiration from the canopy. The TSEB-SM model revises the original TSEB by introducing surface soil moisture stress indices coupled to the evaporation and transpiration algorithm. This allows for more accurate estimation of soil evaporation and plant transpiration across well-watered to extremely dry soil moisture conditions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the key procedural steps in measuring and validating heat fluxes and evapotranspiration estimates at different land cover sites using micrometeorological observations?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The key steps include deploying flux towers over representative surfaces such as grassland, cropland, sparse shrub-forest, and desert steppe. Sensible and latent heat fluxes are measured by eddy covariance systems, and soil moisture and temperature are measured at various depths. The soil moisture measurement at a specific depth is used to calculate the soil stress factor for evaporation. Heat transfer plates are buried with thermocouples to compute the soil heat flux, which, along with the micrometeorological data, is used to evaluate the TSEB-SM and original TSEB models.

Enablement.Question: What data collection techniques enable the production of temporally and spatially continuous land surface evapotranspiration datasets over large regions?
Enablement.Answer: The use of the two-source energy balance (TSEB) model, driven by land surface temperature (LST) and supplemented with surface soil moisture stress indices, enables the production of temporally and spatially continuous land surface evapotranspiration datasets. The model leverages satellite-based thermal infrared data and integrates eddy covariance systems for measuring sensible and latent heat fluxes, allowing for accurate estimation of soil evaporation and plant transpiration across diverse land covers.

Enablement.Question: How do advancements in remote sensing technology enable the accurate representation of evapotranspiration in arid and semi-arid regions?
Enablement.Answer: Advancements in remote sensing, particularly the use of high-resolution satellite soil moisture data from SMAP and MODIS thermal infrared LST data, enable the accurate representation of evapotranspiration in arid and semi-arid regions. These technologies provide soil water boundary conditions for the TSEB-SM model, improving its performance in estimating ET, especially under conditions of soil water stress, and increasing the reliability of ET estimation across varied moisture conditions.

Expectation.Question: Why might a data collection method using thermal infrared data for estimating evapotranspiration face challenges during soil water stress conditions?
Expectation.Answer: Thermal infrared based models using this approach have a systematic positive bias with evapotranspiration during soil water stress conditions.

Expectation.Question: Why could extrapolating measurements of evapotranspiration from canopy and patch scale to regional scales be challenging?
Expectation.Answer: The evapotranspiration and its partitioning can be measured at canopy and patch scale representative areas, but it is very difficult to extrapolate these measurements to field, landscape, and regional scales.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential challenges in scaling local evapotranspiration measurements to larger regional datasets, and how can these be addressed in data collection methods?
Judgmental.Answer: Scaling local evapotranspiration measurements to larger regional datasets presents challenges due to spatial variability in land cover, soil moisture conditions, and atmospheric demand. These issues can lead to difficulties in extrapolating point measurements to broader areas. To address these challenges, integrating in-situ measurements with remote sensing data and employing models like TSEB-SM, which incorporate soil moisture stress indices, can improve the accuracy of scaled estimates. This method can better capture the spatial and temporal variability of evapotranspiration across different landscape scales.

Judgmental.Question: In what ways could the incorporation of soil moisture stress indices into energy balance models improve the estimation of evapotranspiration in drought-prone regions?
Judgmental.Answer: Incorporating soil moisture stress indices into energy balance models, such as the TSEB-SM model, improves evapotranspiration estimation by providing a mechanism to account for water stress conditions that affect plant transpiration and soil evaporation. This enhancement results in more accurate modeling of latent heat fluxes, particularly in drought-prone regions where water availability is limited. The use of soil moisture data from sources like the SMAP satellite allows the model to capture variations in soil moisture content, improving its reliability and accuracy in estimating ET under varying water stress conditions.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how soil moisture data from different depths contribute to the estimation of evapotranspiration components.
Assertion.Answer: Soil moisture data at various depths, particularly at 4 cm, were used to calculate the soil stress factor for soil evaporation, which is crucial for partitioning evapotranspiration into its components. This information was integrated into the TSEB-SM model, which enhances the accuracy of soil evaporation and plant transpiration estimates over diverse soil moisture conditions.
